channel.title: Strange-Influenced Work on
channel.description: Recent content in Strange-Influenced Work on

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Blayne Haggart, Kathryn Henne, Natasha Tusikov. “Introduction.” In Information, Technology and Control in a Changing World: Understanding Power Structures in the 21st Century, edited by Blayne Haggart, Kathryn Henne, Natasha Tusikov, editors. 1-20. Cham: Palgrave Macmillan, 2019. While the control of knowledge is becoming the dominant means by which economic, political, and social control is exerted globally, the mechanisms through which this is happening—including intellectual property rights, state and commercial surveillance, digitisation and datafication, and a nearly ubiquitous internet mediating human interactions—are often examined separately instead of as part of a larger phenomenon of knowledge governance.

item.title: Susan Strange 1923-1998: A Great International Relations Theorist
item.description: Ronen Palan. Review of International Political Economy 6, no. 2 (1999): 121-132. Keywords: Theory; Other Text access (external link)

item.title: 'Take six eggs': theory, finance, and the real economy in the work of Susan Strange
item.description: Robert W. Cox. In Approaches to World Order. Robert W. Cox, Timothy J. Sinclair, editors. 174-187. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1992. Keywords: Theory; Finance Text access (external link)
